content: Hello to everyone who's joined the wg-debugging stream thus far! @Wesley Wiser and @pnkfelix are still working out exactly what our plans are here, and as part of that, I wanted to try to gauge people's interest/planned involvement

Specifically, I wanted to know which people are interested in participating at a somewhat dedicated level of engaging in recurring meetings (similar to weekly triage), helping with issue management or other organization stuff, ...

... versus which people are solely interested in specific domain specific topics (e.g. gdb support, or improving our DWARF output, etc), and are not planning to be following along every week with whatever is happening ...

... (And I'm sure there are other categories of people, such as those who are interested in using debuggers but do not feel comfortable putting themselves into either of the aforementioned buckets yet. I care about you too! You're our "customers", to use Amazon speak. :smile: !)
Anyway, feel free to say Hi, and maybe put a :+1: into whichever of the above buckets you think you fall into. If its bucket #3, I invite you to say more about it.

Hi, i'm unsure what bucket I fit in exactly.
I haven't yet contributed to rust, but motivated by the 'rust compiler ambitions' blog post I would like to help out with the debugging initiative.
I have written my own compiler frontend to x86 backend but don't have any particular experience with debuggers, except for using gdb every now and then.
Eventually, I'd love to be in the first bucket but want to get my feet wet first.
I expect recurring meetings to happen here on Zulip, so the bar for "listening in" should be rather low.

I'm interested in participating at a "somewhat dedicated" level.

(I'm currently in China and will be for a few more months, so my timezone is inhospitable to attending much of anything, but upon my return to the UK, I'll be more actively participating)

I don't have a ton of time to dedicate, but I'd love to help out in three ways:

  • @Yoshua Wuyts [he/they] and I started working on a VS Code extension that conforms to the VS Code debugger adapter protoco. This could be a way for us to experiment with more Rust specific debugger front end experiences.
  • PM work: I'd be happy to do a bit of project management work.
  • Documentation: It would be fantastic if we not only had great debugger support but also world class documentation for how to use various debuggers to debug Rust

I am potentially interested in contributing depending on how relevant rust-minidump is to this (rust-minidump is mozilla's ongoing rewrite of breakpad, the multi-platform minidump writer/analyzer; the analyzer side is good enough that we're running it in production. the writer side is ramping up.)

As Pernosco is becoming a part of what we do in Rustc Reading Club along with gdb, I expect that I will learn more about how and where I can contribute with time. Our use is unique I suppose, but I would like to take what I learn there and apply it to debugging in rustc.

I am the creator of the LLDB debugger and happy to help scope out what work can be done within LLDB to make rust debugging better for developers. I also know quite a bit about DWARF after having dealt with DWARF for over 20 years in developer tools. So I am happy to attend meetings when time permits and also answer any questions people might have on anything debugging related.

Hello, I am working on debugging support in IntelliJ Rust. Besides IDE-specific things, I am the author of GDB/LLDB pretty-printers, originally written for IntelliJ Rust and shipped with rustc since 1.46. I am also developing custom LLDB versions bundled with JetBrains IDEs.

I would like to attend the meetings periodically, and probably contribute to rustc. As for domain-specific topics, I am mostly interested in improving LLDB support and debuginfo generation (DWARF and PDB).
